name: ArgumentPrinciple
probTex:
Let $\Omega$ be a region and suppose $f$ is a meromorphic function on $\Omega$. Let $\gamma$ be a positively oriented simple closed curve which does not pass through any zeroes or poles of $f$. Then
\[\int_\gamma\frac{f'(z)}{f(z)}dz=(2\pi i)(Z-P)\]
where $Z,P$ are the numbers of zeroes and poles of $f$, respectively, which lie in the region bounded by $\gamma$.
Note that by the chain rule (u-substitution),
\[\int_\gamma\frac{f'(z)}{f(z)}dz=\int_{f\circ\gamma}\frac{1}{z}dz\]
is simply the winding number of the image of $\gamma$ around the origin.
solnTex:
Factor the zeroes and poles of $f$ to get
\[f(z)=g(z)\prod_{i=1}^n(z-z_i)\prod_{j=1}^m\frac{1}{z-p_j}.\]
Here $z_1,\ldots,z_n$ are the zeroes of $f$ and $p_1,\ldots,p_m$ are the poles. Note that $g$ has no roots or poles inside $\gamma$. Compute the logarithmic derivative of $f$, not $f'$ directly:
\[\frac{f'(z_0)}{f(z_0)}=\frac{\partial}{\partial z}\ln(f(z))|_{z=z_0}\]
\[\ln(f(z))=\ln(g(z))+\sum_{i=1}^n\ln(z-z_i)-\sum_{j-1}^m\ln(z-p_j).\]
Then take the integral
\[\int_\gamma(\ln(f(z))'dz=\int_\gamma(\ln(g(z))'dz+\sum_{i=1}^n\int_\gamma(\ln(z-z_i))'dz-\sum_{j-1}^m\int_\gamma(\ln(z-p_j))'dz\]
\[=\int_\gamma\frac{g'(z)}{g(z)}dz+\sum_{i=1}^n\int_\gamma\frac{1}{z-z_i}dz-\sum_{j=1}^m\frac{1}{z-p_j}dz.\]
Recall $g$ has no poles or roots inside $\gamma$, so $\frac{g'}{g}$ is a holomorphic function inside $\gamma$. Thus by Cauchy's integral theorem $\int_\gamma\frac{g'(z)}{g(z)}dz=0$. The rest of the terms pick up a copy of $2\pi i$ for each term because $\int_{|z|=1}\frac{1}{z}dz=2\pi i$. Thus
\[\int_\gamma\frac{f'(z)}{f(z)}dz=0+\sum_{i=1}^n(2\pi i)-\sum_{j=1}^m(2\pi i)=2\pi i(n-m)\]
which is the statement.
Note that you can replace $f(z)$ by $f(z)-a$ to count poles and preimages of $a$, just use the argument principle on $g(z)=f(z)-a$.
